name: Cold Miso Soup (Hiyajiru)
description: Known as Hiyajiru in Japan, this Cold Miso Soup is all that you need to nourish your body on hot summer days! It‘s deeply flavorful and includes seasonal vegetables and grilled protein of your choice, making it one of the best cold soups to enjoy. Ready in 15 minutes! {Vegan Adaptable}
recipeIngredient: ¼ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt
10  shiso leaves (perilla/ooba) ((or use chopped green onions))

recipeInstructions.name: To Make the Dashi (Japanese Soup Stock)

itemListElement.text: First, make the dashi. Add 2½ cups water and 1 dashi packet to a saucepan, and bring it to a simmer on medium heat. Let it steep for 2–3 minutes on medium-low heat. Remove from the heat and let the saucepan cool over a bowl of iced water. For vegans/vegetarians, you can make Kombu Dashi.
itemListElement.name: First, make the dashi. Add 2½ cups water and 1 dashi packet to a saucepan, and bring it to a simmer on medium heat. Let it steep for 2–3 minutes on medium-low heat. Remove from the heat and let the saucepan cool over a bowl of iced water. For vegans/vegetarians, you can make Kombu Dashi.

recipeInstructions.name: To Prepare the Sesame and Miso

itemListElement.text: On a baking sheet lined with aluminum foil, spread 4 Tbsp miso.
itemListElement.name: On a baking sheet lined with aluminum foil, spread 4 Tbsp miso.

itemListElement.text: Toast the miso in a toaster oven or the oven broiler for several minutes (8 minutes for my toaster oven) until the surface is slightly charred. Remove from the toaster/broiler and let cool.
itemListElement.name: Toast the miso in a toaster oven or the oven broiler for several minutes (8 minutes for my toaster oven) until the surface is slightly charred. Remove from the toaster/broiler and let cool.

itemListElement.text: Add 2 Tbsp toasted white sesame seeds to a Japanese mortar, reserving some sesame seeds for garnish later. Using a Japanese wooden pestle, grind the sesame seeds.
itemListElement.name: Add 2 Tbsp toasted white sesame seeds to a Japanese mortar, reserving some sesame seeds for garnish later. Using a Japanese wooden pestle, grind the sesame seeds.

itemListElement.text: Add the toasted miso to the mortar and set it aside (we‘ll mix them with the chilled dashi later).
itemListElement.name: Add the toasted miso to the mortar and set it aside (we‘ll mix them with the chilled dashi later).

itemListElement.text: Peel the skin of 4 oz Japanese or Persian cucumber in stripes by alternating peeled and unpeeled strips down the length of the cucumber. Then, thinly slice it.
itemListElement.name: Peel the skin of 4 oz Japanese or Persian cucumber in stripes by alternating peeled and unpeeled strips down the length of the cucumber. Then, thinly slice it.

itemListElement.text: Transfer the cucumber slices to a tray or plate and sprinkle with ¼ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt. Gently rub the cucumber slices with your hands. The salt will draw out the moisture from the cucumber slices and make them crisp. Set aside for 5 minutes.
itemListElement.name: Transfer the cucumber slices to a tray or plate and sprinkle with ¼ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt. Gently rub the cucumber slices with your hands. The salt will draw out the moisture from the cucumber slices and make them crisp. Set aside for 5 minutes.

itemListElement.text: Remove the stems of 10 shiso leaves (perilla/ooba) and roll them up. Cut them into julienned strips. Set aside.
itemListElement.name: Remove the stems of 10 shiso leaves (perilla/ooba) and roll them up. Cut them into julienned strips. Set aside.

itemListElement.text: Break up 1 fillet cooked salmon into smaller pieces. Squeeze the cucumber slices to remove the moisture. Keep all the ingredients on a tray or plate.
itemListElement.name: Break up 1 fillet cooked salmon into smaller pieces. Squeeze the cucumber slices to remove the moisture. Keep all the ingredients on a tray or plate.

recipeInstructions.name: To Assemble and Serve the Soup

itemListElement.text: When the dashi is cold and the toasted miso is no longer hot, pour a small portion of the dashi into the mortar. Using a silicone spatula or spoon, stir well to dissolve the miso in the stock.
itemListElement.name: When the dashi is cold and the toasted miso is no longer hot, pour a small portion of the dashi into the mortar. Using a silicone spatula or spoon, stir well to dissolve the miso in the stock.

itemListElement.text: Once the miso is dissolved completely, add the rest of the dashi and mix it all together.
itemListElement.name: Once the miso is dissolved completely, add the rest of the dashi and mix it all together.

itemListElement.text: Cube 7 oz medium-firm tofu (momen dofu) (the Japanese usually cut tofu while holding it on their palm, but you can cut it into ½-inch (1.3 cm) cubes on a cutting board first). Add the cubed tofu to the mortar. Then, add the salmon pieces.
itemListElement.name: Cube 7 oz medium-firm tofu (momen dofu) (the Japanese usually cut tofu while holding it on their palm, but you can cut it into ½-inch (1.3 cm) cubes on a cutting board first). Add the cubed tofu to the mortar. Then, add the salmon pieces.

itemListElement.text: Add the cucumber and shiso leaves. You can chill the soup longer in the refrigerator or you can serve it immediately in individual bowls. Typically, Cold Miso Soup is served with steamed rice. Some enjoy it by pouring the soup over rice or vice versa.
itemListElement.name: Add the cucumber and shiso leaves. You can chill the soup longer in the refrigerator or you can serve it immediately in individual bowls. Typically, Cold Miso Soup is served with steamed rice. Some enjoy it by pouring the soup over rice or vice versa.

itemListElement.text: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container for 2–3 days. You do not need to reheat. Enjoy it chilled.

review.reviewBody: Have made this a couple of times since first seeing this recipe last year, and it’s something that my partner and I keep returning to, especially on hot summer days! Perhaps quite unorthodox, but we love to add some cooked somen noodles to the hiyajiru directly to make it a full meal :) thank you for sharing this recipe with us!
Made this Cold Miso Soup --- delicious and perfect for a hot & humid summer day.

I have had no luck finding shiso leaves in my area and unfortunately the seeds I planted this spring never sprouted. But I find the taste of shiso may be approximated by a combination of fresh basil leaves and a little mint. Maybe those are more easily sourced for you.
